posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked: Hi! We are thinking to make DIY button board. But I don’t what I need to buy for making button board. Can someone share links what I needed for doing button board and example of your boards?

While we didn’t make a button, what we did was make an app that we could use to select where to score.

image 1889×986 177 KB

image 1889×986 177 KB

image 1889×986 177 KB

It runs on windows, and we bought a touchscreen monitor that we plugged into our DS , and then dragged onto the second screen. The app then communicates to the Robot over NT4, and would publish the values from the app into an AppScoring topic. We then have a ScoringApp class which just allows us to access these values in code.

We decided to make an app because we could hold a lightweight tablet, as well as being able to easily change the layout whenever we wanted.

link_counts.title: GitHub - FRCTeam1672/Reefscape-Scoring-App: 1672's Autonomous Scoring App for the 2025 FRC Season Reefscape

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked: yes I am thinking to buy this but I am not sure these buttons is enough. Also I saw some teams using switches.

We used this . Keep in mind that you should double check that your laptop can actually run a touchscreen monitor. Our (overkill) laptop has a thunderbolt port, so we could just use 1 wire, and that is partially the reason we selected this specific monitor.

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked: why do you guys built your app with flutter? is because it can run with any device? Also is there too much latency?

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
We took an off-the-shelf 3-button, 1-dial macro keyboard , programmed the dial to send ctrl-shift-left and ctrl-shift-right and keys to send modified function key keystrokes, then wrote a short python program to listen for those key events and adjust our targetID on the reef, then eventually on the reef, feeders, and barge.

End result, we had a cheap, fast, and easy dial for our navigator to use.

The python code isn’t in an open repo, but I’ll paste it here.

NB: For whatever reason, the python program doesn’t see the keystrokes if the driver station is the frontmost app.

Edit to correct: it looks like the code does handle the elevator level setting from the F-keys. I was just looking in the wrong spot in the code previously.

You could/should delete the entire if statement for if event.is_keypad: That was me testing the code and is not useful to you. (I would delete it above, but then I’d be sending you code that isn’t the code we’re actually running and I’d rather not risk that breaking things without being able to test it.)

link_counts.title: How does your driver control which branch the robot aligns to? (with vision)

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked: Thanks! it looks like this is the cheapest solution compared to others.

While yes it can technically run on any device, we designed it to run in windows. We originally planned to have an android tablet which would then be connected over USB to send data, but we decided against that.  So that’s why we kind of picked Flutter, however, the main reason was that I was very comfortable in flutter, so I picked that . The reason I say windows is because the driver station runs windows, so we planned to run it with windows, however, it should work on any platform.

The latency has been fine for us. It updates the NT4 topic every 500ms, not the app contents updating every 500ms. Realistically, if 500ms is too slow for you, I dont think I can help

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked: Thanks! It gives me another option.

posts.name: Dkt01
posts.cooked: In 2019 and 2023 we went the full-custom route with panel-mount arcade buttons on a laser-cut MDF box.  It was a lot of work, bulky to carry around, and because of this we only ever had one at a time.  This year we’ve been using an RP2040-based macropad from Adafruit with some Kailh box jade keyswitches to make button presses nice and clicky.  Taking this approach allows us to have two complete robot setups while we do driver practice and software development.  The macropad can be programmed with micropython and can be configured to enumerate as a gamepad with a bunch of buttons, which makes it super simple on the robot code side.

link_counts.title: Adafruit MACROPAD RP2040 Bare Bones - 3x4 Keys + Encoder + OLED : ID 5100 : Adafruit Industries, Unique & fun DIY electronics and kits
Amazon.com: Zjmehty Kailh Box Jade Switches for Mechanical Gaming Keyboard,3-Pin 50gf Clicky/lubed/Dust&Waterproof Switches(36Pcs,Kailh Box Jade) : Video Games
